p: Mikania cordata (Burm. f.) B.L. Robinson, the only congener of the notorious invasive weed Mikania micrantha H.B. Kunth in China, is an herbaceous stem-twiner native to tropical Asia [ 1]. Mikania cordata is distributed restrictively in Southeast Asia and South China including Hainan, Taiwan, and southeast Yunnan [ 1]. It is used as an ethnomedicinal plant in the treatment of cuts and wounds [ 2]. Mikania comprising ca. 450 species is the largest genus in the tribe Eupatorieae of the Asteraceae family [ 1]. There are only two species of the genus Mikania in China: a native species M. cordata and an introduced species M. micrantha [ 1]. Both are perennial vines with slender stems, heart-shaped leaves, and pappus-bearing achenes [ 1, 3]. Their appearance so closely resembles each other that it is hard to distinguish M. cordata from M. micrantha [ 4, 5].
